text: Private Eye has the preview for next week sorted
author: rosschawkins

text: great - thanks v much
author: rosschawkins

text: I wasn't there for that. Intriguing. Starmer line in House had been:
author: rosschawkins

text: Interesting chatter among some MPs about whether govt could split Withdrawal Agreement from Political Declaration to try to get assent for first. Loads of issues with that but Jill's blog worth a read
author: rosschawkins

text: And David Lidington still busy this morning. Lib Dem leader Vince Cable expected to see him
author: rosschawkins

text: Before news overnight some backers of indicative votes feared that strategy was shot because time was running out. Extension helps keep the possibility on table
author: rosschawkins

text: Been called much worse
author: rosschawkins

text: Current toast of Brexiteers: Pres Macron. If it’s May deal v no deal they’re v happy with that
author: rosschawkins

text: Opposing wings of Theresa May’s party united in baffled horror at her statement last night, but it’s the Brexiteers with a spring in their step here
author: rosschawkins

text: Excellent watch. Not least for the fabulously patronising tone of the 1973 reporter
author: rosschawkins

text: v cheering - glad you tweeted this, would never have stumbled across otherwise
author: rosschawkins

text: How do PM words and letter fit with House's rejection of no deal?
author: rosschawkins

text: Alison McGovern has applied for an SO24 debate. Motion has to be vague but allows MPs chance to debate Brexit again after news overnight if granted
author: rosschawkins

text: Tory Mp reflecting on the ERG tells me Prime Minister needs to “face the f***ers down”.
author: rosschawkins

text: Eek - Cabinet source: this is the move that ensures she stays in No10 avoiding decision. It will not work as a strategy for getting the deal through. This is not what Parliament voted for last week.
author: rosschawkins

text: Craftily worded indeed. Motion language far softer than Commons language. Basically just speculates about EU reaction.
author: rosschawkins

text: Compare contrast. Number 10 today: “PM won’t be asking for a long extension. There is a case for giving Parliament a bit more time to agree a way forward, but the people of this country have been waiting nearly three years now.“ Theresa May on March 13:
author: rosschawkins

text: And Labour potential rebels won't move unless...
author: rosschawkins

text: bashes Erskine May dust off boots
author: rosschawkins

text: For this reason, a very senior Conservative tells me "Bercow has f***ed himself" - says he'll kill off all the Brexit ideas he might like as well as the ones he might not
author: rosschawkins

text: Erg Mp on Bercow statement: it’s a good result. Clock’s ticking. Makes no deal more likely
author: rosschawkins

text: Govt can not resubmit the same or substantially the same proposition as last week he says. And notes he may have more to say.
author: rosschawkins

text: If this turns into - you can have your vote but draft a document or two to go with it that may not rock world on its axis
author: rosschawkins

text: Bercow appears to be wielding hefty spanner to lob into works here
author: rosschawkins

text: Speaker reminds govt he gets to decide if repeated meaningful votes are too similar to be heard again - citing 19th Century precedent
author: rosschawkins

text: And what if PM were to give a departure date and still lose
author: rosschawkins

text: stuff happens, sentiment changes, people u-turn but v hard to imagine govt whips getting to end of today and reliably thinking - no question, we've got this
author: rosschawkins

text: From few chats this morning - as reported by others, plenty of Cons MPs demanding both pledge of May's departure and DUP endorsement to back deal. And if core of Brexiteers holds out STILL going to be relying on fresh Labour backbench support.
author: rosschawkins

text: One recipient of a weekend phone call from the Prime Minister tells me they came off phone less convinced than when they picked up
author: rosschawkins
